did.head: Collection Summary
did.abstract: Biologist, ecologist, and environmental activist. Correspondence, speeches, writings, research files, subject files, organizational files, printed matter, photographs in both physical and digital formats, and other papers documenting Commoner's career as a biologist, ecologist, and environmental activist. Subjects include the physiochemical basis of biological processes, moral obligations of scientists, ecology, and the politics of environmental stewardship.

controlaccess.head: Selected Search Terms
controlaccess.p: The following terms have been used to index the description of this collection in the LC Catalog. They are grouped by name of person or organization, by subject or location, and by occupation and listed alphabetically.

persname.part: Commoner, Barry, 1917-2012. Closing circle; nature, man, and technology. 1971.
Commoner, Barry, 1917-2012. Making peace with the planet. 1990.
Commoner, Barry, 1917-2012. Poverty of power : energy and the economic crisis. 1976.

Committee for Environmental Information (Saint Louis, Mo.)
Greater St. Louis Citizens' Committee for Nuclear Information.
United States. Office of Naval Research.
Washington University (Saint Louis, Mo.). Center for the Biology of Natural Systems.

acqinfo.head: Acquisition Information
acqinfo.p: The papers of Barry Commoner were given to the Library of Congress by Commoner in 1981. Additions to the collection were given by Commoner to the Library in 2011 and 2014.

processinfo.head: Processing History
processinfo.p: In 1983, Dr. Commoner requested to conduct research in his own papers. As the collection was unprocessed, staff hastily assembled material in document boxes and created a cursory inventory. Though inadequately arranged and described, the papers remained in this condition and, over time, were treated as processed and served to researchers. In 1990, material from the 1981 gift not included in the original finding aid was processed as the first addition to the papers by Connie Cartledge. At that time, the disorder of the original collection was noted but not addressed. The finding aid was revised in 2013. After Dr. Commoner's death in 2012, a final gift was received in 2014 and processed with the 2011 gift as the 2019 addition by Karen Linn Femia with the assistance of Dan Oleksiw. The digital material was processed by Amanda Loeb. While processing this addition, it was decided to remedy the problems of the original collection from 1983. The original collection material was processed by Karen Linn Femia with the assistance of Tracey Barton and Emily Flint. Because of the limited onsite work allowed during the 2020 pandemic, processing was completed in 2021 by Emily Flint and the finding aid was completed and revised by Karen Linn Femia while teleworking. Some items in the Barry Commoner Papers have undergone mold remediation.

Previous researchers should note the following changes that greatly improve accessibility to the collection. The Personal File and Speeches and Writings file series remain in the original order and boxes, but are now more fully described. Because the original order is not alphabetical, the container list gives the intellectual order rather than the physical order; box numbers are not sequential. The Subject File was too problematic to maintain in its original order and has been fully re-organized. Part of this series was added to the end of Speeches and Writings, part became a new Correspondence series, part was interfiled in the Organizations File, and the remainder was processed as the Subject File. The Organizations File has likewise been re-organized, exchanging small amounts of material with the Subject File.

Digital photograph files were received on a CD as part of the 2019 Addition to the Barry Commoner Papers and can be accessed with a file viewer tool. Use the digital ID to request access copies of the files.

separatedmaterial.head: Transfers
separatedmaterial.p: Sound recordings, videocassettes, and filmstrips have been transferred to the Library's Motion Picture, Broadcasting, and Recorded Sound Division where they are identified as part of the Barry Commoner Papers.

userestrict.head: Copyright Status
userestrict.p: The status of copyright in the unpublished writings of Barry Commoner is governed by the Copyright Law of the United States (Title 17, U.S.C.).

accessrestrict.head: Access and Restrictions
accessrestrict.p: The papers of Barry Commoner are open to research. Many collections are stored off-site and advance notice is needed to retrieve these items for research use. Access to digital content is available onsite only in the Manuscript Reading Room and requires advanced notice. Researchers are advised to contact the Manuscript Reading Room prior to visiting.

phystech.head: Technical Requirements
phystech.p: Digital files were received as part of the 2019 addition to the papers of Barry Commoner on a CD, and were assigned a unique digital ID number. The content is image files in .jpg format. Use the digital ID number to request access copies of the files. Consult reference staff in the Manuscript Division for more information.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Researchers wishing to cite this collection should include the following information: Container or digital ID number, Barry Commoner Papers, Manuscript Division, Library of Congress, Washington, D.C.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Note
scopecontent.p: The papers of Barry Commoner (1917-2012 ) span the years 1915-2009, with the bulk of the material dating from 1940 to 1990. The collection documents Commoner's career as a biologist, ecologist, writer, and environmental activist. The papers are organized into seven series: Personal File, Speeches and Writings File, Correspondence, Subject File, Organizations File, with a 1990 Addition and a 2019 Addition. Researchers should keep in mind that the additions are sizeable with many repetitions of file names and folder headings from the original accession.

Commoner, one of the founders of the environmental movement and a political activist, was a professor of plant physiology and botany for many years at Washington University in St. Louis, Missouri. He researched and published extensively on the tobacco mosaic virus (for which he received the 1953 Newcomb Cleveland Prize) and the role of free radicals. In addition to his purely scientific publications, Commoner wrote books on environmentalism and the social aspects of science for the general public. Indeed, providing scientific knowledge to the general public was the core of his political activism.

Commoner’s political activism began with opposition to aboveground nuclear weapons testing and the danger of radioactive fallout. In 1957, in collaboration with Linus Pauling, Commoner wrote and distributed a letter calling for an end to nuclear testing. Signed by thousands of scientists, it was presented to the president of the United States and to the United Nations. In 1958 Commoner helped found the Greater St. Louis Committee for Nuclear Information (CNI). The Baby Tooth Survey, conducted by CNI with Commoner as one of the leaders, collected over two hundred thousand baby teeth to measure the rising levels of radioactive strontium-90 in children’s bodies, the result of fallout that had spread across the country from nuclear weapons testing in Nevada. The Baby Tooth Survey attracted wide public attention, generating opposition to the nuclear tests and influencing the signing of the 1963 Nuclear Test Ban Treaty. Commoner considered this the first victory of the environmental movement.

The core of Commoner’s philosophy of environmental activism was already at the heart of the Baby Tooth Survey: a belief that scientists have a moral obligation to explain science to the general public so the public, not just scientists and politicians, can make informed decisions about science policy. He called this the “science information movement.” The other cornerstone of his environmental thinking was his conviction that unless the means of production, especially energy production, changed, environmental degradation could not be stemmed, thus requiring political solutions. With the goal of establishing a new, progressive, environmentally-engaged political party, Commoner ran as the presidential Nominee of the Citizens Party in 1980.
The collection’s series are listed and briefly described below. A fuller description of each series and a list of its contents can be accessed in the series descriptions within the container list.
The Personal File primarily consists of a general correspondence file and telephone logs along with agendas, appointment books, diaries, and notebooks.

The Speeches and Writings File includes drafts and published copies of his scientific writings, drafts and reviews of his books intended for the general public, and items documenting speaking engagements.
The Correspondence series consists of professional correspondence, received and sent, and includes some drafts of outgoing correspondence.
The Subject File contains material identified by topic, personal name, material type, or name of organization.
The Organizations File includes only those organizations that Commoner either founded, had leadership positions in, or was otherwise heavily involved with.
The 1990 Addition is arranged into six subseries: General Correspondence, Speeches and Writings, Subject File, Research File, Photographs and Slides, and Miscellany.
The 2019 Addition contains material received in 2011 and 2014. This addition is arranged into four subseries and an oversize: a Clippings File, Research File, Speeches and Writings, and Subject File.

arrangement.head: Arrangement of the Papers
arrangement.p: This collection is arranged in seven series:

scopecontent.p: The Personal File is primarily comprised of a general correspondence file and telephone logs along with other material documenting Commoner’s activities and appointments. The telephone logs include notes about the content of conversations or messages. The general correspondence is the bulk of the series. For Commoner's professional correspondence, consult the Correspondence series.
Material types include correspondence, telephone logs, agendas, appointment books, diaries, itineraries, and notebooks.

arrangement.p: Arranged alphabetically by type of material and chronologically therein.

scopecontent.p: The Speeches and Writings File includes drafts and published copies of his scientific writings, drafts and reviews of his books intended for the general public, items documenting speaking engagements in the chronological file, and related correspondence and production material for publication projects. The book file includes drafts for his bestselling books The Closing Circle (1971), Making Peace with the Planet (1990), The Poverty of Power (1976), and Science and Survival (1966). The files for his scientific articles include research notes, draft writings, and published copies. Both the 1990 Addition and the 2019 Addition have a Speeches and Writings subseries containing related material.
Material types include draft writings, published articles, book reviews, correspondence, production material, and reports.

arrangement.p: Arranged alphabetically by type of writing or material into the following categories: Article file, Book file, Chronological file of articles and speaking engagements, Drafts file (chronological), Drafts file (by topic or title), Invitations declined or cancelled, Manuscripts reviewed, Newsletters and journals, and Reports.

scopecontent.p: Professional correspondence, received and sent, including some drafts of outgoing correspondence.
Material types include correspondence with occasional attachments of printed matter.

arrangement.p: Arranged alphabetically by correspondent and chronologically by year therein, with outgoing drafts at the end.

scopecontent.p: The Subject File contains material identified by topic, personal name, material type, or name of organization. (Note that select organization files are in the Organizations series.) Major topics include biology and botany, civil defense, ecology, environmental pollution, energy, genetics, Italy’s dioxin accident at Seveso, nuclear technologies, peaceful uses of atomic energy, population growth, radiation and radioactive fallout, and the Vietnam War. Margaret Mead, Ralph Nader, Linus Pauling, and Albert Szent-Gyorgi have files in this series. Among the many organizations represented are the United States Office of Naval Research and the U.S. Atomic Energy Commission.
Material types include correspondence, reports, printed matter, news clippings, research notes, files of published scientific articles, and research notebooks.

arrangement.p: Arranged alphabetically by topic, name of individual, material type, or name of organization.

scopecontent.p: Organizations that Commoner either founded, had leadership positions in, or was heavily involved with. This series also includes material from his faculty years at Washington University in St. Louis, Missouri.
Material types include correspondence, reports, committee papers, speeches and events material, financial records, and other related material.

arrangement.p: Arranged alphabetically by name of organization into the following subseries: American Association for the Advancement of Science (AAAS), Center for the Biology of Natural Systems (CBNS), Committee for Environmental Information CEI), Greater St. Louis Citizens' Committee for Nuclear Information (CNI), Scientsts' Institute for Public Information (SIPI), and Washington University.

did.unittitle: American Association for the Advancement of Science (AAAS), 1919-1975

scopecontent.p: The files primarily pertain to the AAAS committees in which Commoner was most active: the Committee on the Social Aspects of Science, the Committee on Science in the Promotion of Human Welfare, and the Committee on Environmental Alterations. These particular AAAS committees worked to engage scientists in public policy issues such as radioactive fallout from nuclear weapons testing, air quality, and energy consumption. Also present are files on annual meetings, the board of directors, budgets, and AAAS publications. Prominent correspondents include Chauncey Leake, Margaret Mead, Ward Pigman, and Dael Wolfle. More files pertaining to the AAAS are in both the 1990 and 2019 Additions.
Material types include correspondence, draft writings, committee reports and publications, financial records, minutes of meetings, and printed matter.

arrangement.p: Arranged alphabetically by committee name, topic, or material type.

Center for the Biology of Natural Systems (CBNS), 1951-1980

scopecontent.p: Commoner was the founder and director of the Center for the Biology of Natural Systems (CBNS), an environmental health sciences research center created in 1966 and based at Washington University, where Commoner was a faculty member. CBNS moved to Queens College, City University of New York in 1981. Queens College changed its name to the Barry Commoner Center for Health and the Environment in 2015. More files pertaining to CBNS are in both the 1990 and 2019 Additions.
Material types include correspondence, committee and task force records, grant and financial material, research reports, and speeches and writings.

arrangement.p: Arranged alphabetically by topic material type.

Program of Environmental Education for Students from Developing Countries, 1971-1977
Reference Center on Ecology and International Development, 1971-1975

scopecontent.p: After the passage of the Nuclear Test Ban Treaty in 1963, the Committee for Nuclear Information expanded its mission to include other environmental policy issues and changed its name to the Committee for Environmental Information. Commoner continued in a leadership position. The file includes material on nuclear testing and the U.S. Atomic Energy Commission, and their publications C.E. Eye , Environment , and Scientist and Citizen.
Material types include correspondence, committee and board of directors records, financial records, and printed matter.

arrangement.p: Arranged alphabetically by topic or material type.

did.unittitle: Greater St. Louis Citizens' Committee for Nuclear Information (CNI), 1958-1968

scopecontent.p: Organized in 1958 by a group of scientists, including Commoner, and concerned citizens in St. Louis, Missouri, who believed the public should have accurate information about nuclear energy and radioactive fallout from nuclear weapons testing. Material from the Baby Tooth Survey and the biological effects of radioactive fallout is included here. The organization was one of many committees around the country whose shared name was the Committee for Nuclear Information (CNI). More files pertaining to this organization and the publication Nuclear Information are in the 2019 Addition.
Material types include correspondence, financial records, grant proposals, minutes of meetings, press releases, printed material, and testimonies.

arrangement.p: Arranged alphabetically by topic or material type.

did.unittitle: Newspaper clippings, pamphlets, and other printed matter, 1958-1964

scopecontent.p: Founded in 1963 by Commoner and others as a coordinating body for twenty-three regional Committees for Nuclear/Environmental Information. Over time, the affiliates ceased operating and SIPI inherited the mission of delivering accurate scientific information to the public on a wide range of scientific issues affecting public policy. More files pertaining to SIPI are in the 2019 Addition.
Material types include correspondence, newsletters, press releases, meeting agendas and minutes, and financial material.

arrangement.p: Arranged alphabetically by topic or material type.

scopecontent.p: Notebooks, notes, and drafts of scientific research projects and studies by Commoner.

arrangement.p: Arranged alphabetically by name of research topic or type of material.

"Physical Mechanisms of Biological Electron Transport: Progress Report," 1963

scopecontent.p: The Speeches and Writings subseries includes book drafts, a chronological file of published articles, speeches, testimonies, and related material. The chronological file reveals Commoner's shifting interests over time and includes a mix of writings on scientific research, public policy, and political issues. The book drafts and reviews of Commoner's books include Air Pollution , Making Peace with the Planet , and The Poverty of Power. The speaking engagements file contains correspondence, publicity, itineraries, travel arrangements, and sometimes speech texts or notes and is chronologically arranged. The speech, conference papers, and testimonies file is also arranged chronologically but only contains the written texts.
Material types include drafts and published writings, speech texts, related correspondence and printed matter, itineraries, and travel material.

arrangement.p: Arranged alphabetically by type of writing and chronologically therein; the book file is arranged alphabetically.

scopecontent.p: The Subject File holds organization files, biographical material, including items from Commoner's military service, a file on Linus Pauling and their work together opposing nuclear weapons testing, documents from Commoner's consultant work concerning the dioxin accident in Seveso, Italy, photographs and portraits of Commoner, and other topical material. The organizations represented in the Subject File that were central to Commoner's career include the American Association for the Advancement of Science (AAAS), Center for the Biology of Natural Systems (CBNS), the Citizens Party, the Greater St. Louis Citizens' Committee for Nuclear Information, and the Scientists' Institute for Public Information (SIPI).
Material types include correspondence, biographical material, digital content, photographs, reports, and printed matter.

arrangement.p: Arranged alphabetically by topic or name of organization or person. File structure of the digital content maintained as received.

scopecontent.p: Items from awards and honors received by Commoner and from a celebration of his eightieth birthday. Also included is a membership list for the Citizens Party, the progressive political party co-founded by Commoner.

arrangement.p: Arranged and described according to the series, containers, and folders from which the items were separated.
